Title.evidence: A Randomised Controlled Trial Comparing Pressure-Controlled and Volume-Controlled Ventilation in Rhinoplasty

Trial_Design.evidence: This double-blind, randomised controlled trial was conducted at Hazrat-e Fatemeh Hospital, Iran University of Medical Sciences, from 2021 to 2022.

Participants.evidence: Sixty patients aged 18-50 years, classified as ASA I or II, were randomised to receive either pressure-controlled ventilation (PCV) or volume-controlled ventilation (VCV) during rhinoplasty.

Intervention.evidence: Sixty patients aged 18-50 years, classified as ASA I or II, were randomised to receive either pressure-controlled ventilation (PCV) or volume-controlled ventilation (VCV) during rhinoplasty.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome, intraoperative bleeding, was measured by weighing blood-soaked gauze and suctioned fluid. The timeframe for measurement was the duration of the surgery.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was achieved using a table of random numbers, with allocation concealed in sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Both patients and surgeons were blinded to group assignments.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Sixty patients aged 18-50 years, classified as ASA I or II, were randomised to receive either pressure-controlled ventilation (PCV) or volume-controlled ventilation (VCV) during rhinoplasty.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Fifty-eight patients completed the study, with 31 in the PCV group and 27 in the VCV group.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The mean intraoperative bleeding volume was 30 ± 45 mL in the PCV group and 100 ± 120 mL in the VCV group (P < 0.001). Logistic regression analysis showed that the odds of experiencing moderately severe or severe bleeding were 5.4 times higher in the VCV group, increasing to 26.8 (95% CI = 1.2, 59.3) after adjusting for confounders.

Harms.evidence: No adverse events were reported in either group.
